original_prompt: In this task, you are given a tuple, comprising Head and Tail, separated with <sep>. The Head and the Tail events are short phrases possibly involving participants. The names of specific people have been replaced by generic words (e.g., PersonX, PersonY, PersonZ). PersonX is always the subject of the event. You have to determine whether, as a result of the Head, PersonY or others will want what is mentioned in the Tail or not. In this task, wanting is a postcondition desire on the part of PersonY and others, respectively. For example, as a result of PersonX giving PersonY gifts, PersonY may want to open the gift. Classify your answers into "Yes" and "No". The phrase may also contain "___", a placeholder that can be an object, a person, and/or an action.
generated_prompts: In this task, you are given a tuple of Head and Tail events. The Head and Tail events are short phrases possibly involving participants. In this task, wanting is a postcondition desire on the part of PersonY and others, respectively. For example, as a result of PersonX giving PersonY gifts, PersonY may want to open the gift. Classify your answers into "Yes" and "No". The phrase may also contain "___", a placeholder that can be an object, a person, and/or an action.

In this task, you are given a tuple containing Head and Tail events, separated by <sep>. The Head and Tail events are short phrases involving participants, where the names of specific people have been replaced by generic words. PersonX is always the subject of the event. For example, if the Head event is "PersonX giving PersonY gifts", and the Tail event is "PersonY opening the gift", then the answer would be "Yes". Classify your answers into "Yes" and "No". The phrase may also contain "___", a placeholder that can be an object, a person, and/or an action.
